instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing
threads.message:
Hi guys I have an 3476 with liquid damage at <CAPACITOR>C7622</CAPACITOR> the line was burned. I wired it to <CAPACITOR>C7624</CAPACITOR>. Still there was a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL>. I found <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> a bit hotter then the rest and replaced it. The short circuit is gone and instead 1.2v I get 12.56v on PPBUS. Now the board is power cycling. Vcore goes up to 1V and back to 0 and so is <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> at fan. Could this be related to the liquid? It was only a bit on one spot and the board looks quite OK in general. Any chance that the CPU can be fried as well here? Checked <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and ROM area looks quite clean and voltage is there 3.3v and 3.42v.

Edit: found a short in 1.05 circuit, removed <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> but that didnt remove the short. Rest of components look pretty OK. Since its a low voltage line I figured I better not pump power through it to find the short. Any things I should be checking here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing
threads.message: Resistance between pin 2 of PPBUS fuse and VCore? If anything low, this is trash.

threads.message: Thanks for the help anyway John! Much appreciated.
